question.Title: Why does WinApi typedef basic datatypes?
question.Body:
So I was reading through some WinApi files and found these:

#define CALLBACK    __stdcall#define WINAPI      __stdcall#define WINAPIV     __cdecl#define APIENTRY    WINAPI#define APIPRIVATE  __stdcall#define PASCAL      __stdcall#define FAR                 far#define NEAR                neartypedef float               FLOAT;typedef int                 INT;typedef unsigned int        UINT;#define VOID voidtypedef char CHAR;typedef short SHORT;typedef long LONG;

I also found this on Gdiplus' files:

typedef float REAL;

Why do libraries do this?Why do they want to typedef the most basic things with a new name of just the same but in all caps?Why do they define the same things multiple times?Seems really useless to me and just more confusing and annoying.
